current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to
		  include information on the coverage of intensive behavioral therapy for obesity
		  in the Medicare and You Handbook and to provide for the coordination of
		  programs to prevent and treat obesity, and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the
			 following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text:
Treat and Reduce Obesity Act of
			 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
makes the following
			 findings:

, about 35 percent of adults aged 65 and over were obese
			 in the period of 2007 through 2010, representing over 8 million adults aged 65
			 through 74.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Centers for Disease
			 Control and Prevention

text.#text: According to the

Obesity increases the risk for chronic
			 diseases and conditions, including high blood pressure, heart disease, and type
			 2 diabetes.

More than half of Medicare beneficiaries
			 are treated for 5 or more chronic conditions per year. The rate of obesity
			 among Medicare patients doubled from 1987 to 2002, and spending on those
			 individuals more than doubled.

Obese men and women at age 65 have
			 decreased life expectancy of 1.6 years for men and 1.4 years for women.

The direct and
			 indirect cost of obesity is more than $450 billion annually.

On average, an
			 obese Medicare beneficiary costs $1,964 more than a normal-weight
			 beneficiary.

The prevalence of
			 obesity among older Americans is growing at a linear rate and, left unchanged,
			 nearly half of the elderly population will be obese in 2030 according to a
			 Congressional Research Report on obesity.

header.#text:
Inclusion of

			 Medicare and You Handbook

information on

				therapy.

The amendments made by this section shall apply to notices
			 distributed on or after the date of enactment of this Act.

text.#text:
Not later than 1 year
				after the date of enactment of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the

shall work with at least 5
				representatives, selected by the

, of expert organizations (such as

text.#text:
In developing and implementing the
				plan under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall ensure that the
				plan under

is coordinated with the National Prevention
				Strategy and does not duplicate the efforts of the National Prevention Council
				and the National Prevention Strategy.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall
				include the following:

text.#text: The plan under

Strategies to comprehensively treat
				and reduce overweight and obesity.
A description of—

the coordination of interagency
				cooperation under the plan; and

actions under the plan related to
				the treatment and reduction of overweight and obesity in the United
				States.

Identification of best practices in
				States, communities, organizations, businesses, and other entities as
				appropriate, regarding treatment of overweight and obesity.

A description of collaboration with
				States, communities, organizations, businesses, and other appropriate entities
				to evaluate the effectiveness of obesity and overweight interventions under the
				plan.

Research initiatives, including
				ongoing surveillance and monitoring using tools such as the National Health and
				Nutrition Examination Survey and the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System
				and assurances for adequate and consistent funding to support data collection
				and analysis to inform policy under the plan.

Recommendations for the coordination
				of budgets, grant and pilot programs, policies, and programs across Federal
				agencies to cohesively treat overweight and obesity.
